The octanol-water partition coefficients (log P) were calculated as the difference of
the solvation free energy of a substance in water and in aqueous octanol.

column2: two classical molecular dynamics simulations was made: the transition
and transition from vacuum to a saturated solution of water in octanol.

column1: Free energy was determined by Expanded Ensembles method.
The calculations were carried out on the so-called "alchemical coordinate" which was divided into 50-61 windows.
In the first phase consisting of eight passes the balancing factors were determined.
Each pass consisted of two back and forth passes (vacuum - solution) along the alchemical coordinate.

column2: the Verlet integrator with the Bussi-Donadio-Parrinello thermostat

column1: and the Berendsen barostat was used.

column3: statistics were collected for actual calculations of free energy.

column1: The scatter in the number of passes and
column3: in the accuracy of the calculations is due to the fact

column1: that the length of the pass depends on the nature of the substance being modeled.
Statistical uncertainties are indicated on the basis of experience with other substances
column2: depending on the number of passes in the second phase.

column1: The calculations were carried out on personal computers with video cards supporting CUDA technology.
Pre-parametrization of MM models was carried out using an automatic parameterizer of Abalone.
Parameters of non-valent interactions were manually edited in many cases. In particular
column2: based on the experience of the author

column1: parameters for fluorine and chlorine that were missing in the program were added.
The general idea of parameterization is the AMBER/OPLS approach: the potential derived charges are used;
Lennard-Jones parameters are taken in such way that the thermodynamic properties of simple liquids are reproduced.
